intro: Gagea joannis, commonly known as the Sierra gagea, is a small perennial plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces a single, erect stem that bears a cluster of bell-shaped, white or pale pink flowers. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open woodland or rocky habitats. Gagea joannis is adapted to dry, sunny environments and is typically found in mountainous regions.
